elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of 2,2′-biphenyldicarboxylate (H2dpa) and 4,4′-azobispyridine (azpy) in the presence of transition metal ions produce six new complexes, namely, [Co­(dpa)­(bphy)] n (1), [Co­(dpa)­(azpy)­(H2O)] n ·0.5nH2O (2), [Zn­(dpa)­(bphy)] n (3), [Zn­(dpa)­(azpy)­(H2O)] n (4), [Mn­(dpa)­(azpy)­(H2O)] n ·0.5nH2O (5), and [Mn­(dpa)­(azpy)] n ·nH2O·nMeOH (6) (bphy = 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­hydrazine). The crystal structure analyses reveal that complexes 1 and 3 are isostructural which features a plywood-like structure, while complex 4 exhibits a parallel chains array. Complexes 2 and 5 afford a two-dimensional chiral (4,4) network, and complex 6 shows a (4,4) network. It was noteworthy that the in situ reduction of azpy to bphy was found in complexes 1 and 3, which were confirmed by single-crystal structures and LC-MS analyses. However, this in situ reduction was not found at a low reaction temperature in the syntheses of complexes 2, 4, and 5. The second-harmonic-generation (SHG) properties of 1 and 3 and the solid circular dichroism (CD) properties of 2 and 5 were investigated. In addition, luminescent properties of complexes 3 and 4 as well as magnetic properties of complexes 1, 2, 5, and 6 were also studied.

The crystal structure analyses reveal that complexes 1 and 3 are isostructural which features a plywood-like structure, while complex 4 exhibits a parallel chains array. Complexes 2 and 5 afford a two-dimensional chiral (4,4) network, and complex 6 shows a (4,4) network. It was noteworthy that the in situ reduction of azpy to bphy was found in complexes 1 and 3, which were confirmed by single-crystal structures and LC-MS analyses. However, this in situ reduction was not found at a low reaction temperature in the syntheses of complexes 2, 4, and 5. The second-harmonic-generation (SHG) properties of 1 and 3 and the solid circular dichroism (CD) properties of 2 and 5 were investigated. In addition, luminescent properties of complexes 3 and 4 as well as magnetic properties of complexes 1, 2, 5, and 6 were also studied.

elements.content: A series of low-dimensional coordination polymers were prepared under solvothermal conditions using 2,2′-biphenyldicarboxylate (H2dpa) and azo-containing azobispyridine (azpy) in the presence of transition metal ions. In situ formation of bphy from reduction of azpy happened at high temperature in complexes 1 and 3, while it did not happen in complexes 2, 4, and 5 which was obtained at low temperature. Complexes 1 and 3 crystallize in non-centrosymmetric space groups which possess second-harmonic-generation (SHG) efficiencies that are comparable to potassium dihydrogen phosphate. In addition, the Cotton effect in solid circular dichroism of bulky samples for complexes 2 and 5 is significantly observed. The luminescent properties of complexes 3 and 4 and magnetic properties of complexes 1, 2, 5, and 6 were also investigated.

elements.content: The rational design, synthesis, and characterization of coordination polymers have been of current interest in the fields of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering, owing not only to their interesting network topologies and diverse structures but also to their potential applications for magnetism, fluorescence, electronics, gas absorption, ion exchange, heterogeneous catalysis, and so on. Although remarkable achievements have been attained, controlling the structure and the structure–property relationship are still challenges for the complexity of self-assembly and the elusiveness of the reaction mechanism. Recently, hydro­(solvo)­thermal techniques, which may provoke some interest in inorganic and organic reactions such as metal redox, ligand substitution, hydroxylation, and cycloaddition, have been employed to generate coordination complexes with sophisticated architectures and promising properties. Many hydro­(solvo)­thermal reactions accompanied by new ligands generated in situ have been developed as a new approach to the crystal engineering of coordination polymers. Nevertheless, the existence of in situ generation of ligands (especially those that are inaccessible by direct preparation) also makes it difficult to predict the resultant structures. As was widely reported, the self-assembly process is frequently affected by various factors, such as the number, type, and spatial coordinated disposition of the ligands, the stereoelectronic preference of the metal ions, metal–ligand ratios, temperatures, solvents, and counterions. Therefore, the appropriate choice of metal ions together with the multifunctional organic ligands under proper reaction conditions overcomes this crucial problem to the construction of desirable coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rational design, synthesis, and characterization of coordination polymers have been of current interest in the fields of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering, owing not only to their interesting network topologies and diverse structures but also to their potential applications for magnetism, fluorescence, electronics, gas absorption, ion exchange, heterogeneous catalysis, and so on. Although remarkable achievements have been attained, controlling the structure and the structure-property relationship are still challenges for the complexity of self-assembly and the elusiveness of the reaction mechanism. Recently, hydro(solvo)thermal techniques, which may provoke some interest in inorganic and organic reactions such as metal redox, ligand substitution, hydroxylation, and cycloaddition, have been employed to generate coordination complexes with sophisticated architectures and promising properties. Many hydro(solvo)thermal reactions accompanied by new ligands generated in situ have been developed as a new approach to the crystal engineering of coordination polymers. Nevertheless, the existence of in situ generation of ligands (especially those that are inaccessible by direct preparation) also makes it difficult to predict the resultant structures. As was widely reported, the self-assembly process is frequently affected by various factors, such as the number, type, and spatial coordinated disposition of the ligands, the stereoelectronic preference of the metal ions, metal-ligand ratios, temperatures, solvents, and counterions. Therefore, the appropriate choice of metal ions together with the multifunctional organic ligands under proper reaction conditions overcomes this crucial problem to the construction of desirable coordination polymers.

elements.content: In order to build novel coordination polymers, polycarboxylates are often employed as bridging ligands owing to their diverse coordination modes. The 2,2′-biphenyldicarboxylate (H2dpa) offers an excellent choice as a versatile dicarboxylate ligand to assemble coordination polymers due to the distortion of the diphenyl rings from the central bond that endows it diverse coordination behavior. Furthermore, the employment of coligand during the self-assembly process has gradually become an effective approach to obtain structures with more novelty compared to using only one type of ligand. N-donor ligands are often used as coligands owing to their affinities to transition metal ions and their conformations as pillar-like connectors. The 4,4′-azobispyridine (azpy) possesses not only metal-bridging sites but also redox and optical properties introduced by its azo group. Reductions of azo-containing aromatic complexes have been studied extensively which have been focused on their electrochemical behavior analyzed by the method of polarography, cyclic voltammetry, controlled-potential coulometry, electron spin resonance spectroscopy, and ultraviolet spectroscopy. However, few studies involving the reduction of azpy in the synthesis of coordination polymers have been documented. Although the reason for the in situ reduction of azpy affected by temperature has not been studied clearly, it is worthwhile to do.

elements.content: Taking all the above discussions into account, we employed H2dpa and azpy reacting with transition metal ions under solvothermal conditions. A series of complexes were obtained and characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectra, thermogravimetric analyses, powder X-ray diffraction, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. Interestingly, azpy was found to be in situ reduced to 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­hydrazine (bphy) at high temperature in complexes 1 and 3 which exhibit nonlinear optical properties. In addition, H2dpa is capable of generating both a chiral and achiral solids depending on its different coordination modes with transition metal ions. Furthermore, the fluorescence properties of complexes 3 and 4, and magnetic properties of complexes 1, 2, 5, and 6 were investigated.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded in the range of 4000–400 cm–1 with a Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out in the temperature range of 30–1000 °C with a heating rate of 15 °C min–1 on a NETZSCH STA 449C instrument. ESI-MS spectra were measured on a DECAX-30000 LCQ Deca XP Ion Trap spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were collected on a RIGAKU-DMAX 2500 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra of 2 and 5 were recorded on single crystals with KCl pellets between 200 and 650 nm using MOS 450 of Bio Logic. Magnetic data were obtained with a Quantum Design MPMS XL SQUID magnetometer. Emission spectra were recorded on a Horiba Jobin Yvon Fluorolog-3 spectrophotometer analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All reagents and solvents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 with a Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out in the temperature range of 30-1000 °C with a heating rate of 15 °C min-1 on a NETZSCH STA 449C instrument. ESI-MS spectra were measured on a DECAX-30000 LCQ Deca XP Ion Trap spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were collected on a RIGAKU-DMAX 2500 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra of 2 and 5 were recorded on single crystals with KCl pellets between 200 and 650 nm using MOS 450 of Bio Logic. Magnetic data were obtained with a Quantum Design MPMS XL SQUID magnetometer. Emission spectra were recorded on a Horiba Jobin Yvon Fluorolog-3 spectrophotometer analyzer.

elements.content: A mixture of CoCl2·6H2O (0.144 g, 0.6 mmol), H2dpa (0.048 g, 0.2 mmol), azpy (0.036 g, 0.2 mmol), H2O (8 mL), and DMF (2 mL) was sealed in a 24 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and then heated at 160 °C for 4 days. After slowly cooling to room temperature over 24 h, the purple prism crystals suitable for X-ray structural analysis were isolated by filtration, washed with water several times, and dried in air. Yield: ca. 37.12% (based on CoCl2·6H2O). Anal. Calcd for C24H18N4O4Co1: C, 59.39; H, 3.74; N, 11.54. Found: C, 59.34; H, 3.74; N, 11.63. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3455 (w), 2907 (w), 1638 (s), 1530 (m), 1494 (w), 1347 (m), 830 (m), 746 (m), 672 (m).

elements.content: A solution of CoCl2·6H2O (0.144 g, 0.6 mmol), H2dpa (0.048 g, 0.2 mmol), azpy (0.036 g, 0.2 mmol), H2O (8 mL), and DMF (2 mL) was sealed in a 15 mL scintillation vial. elements.content: The single-crystal structure data of complexes 1, 4, and 6 were determined by Mercury CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71071 Å) radiation at room temperature. Complexes 2 and 5 were determined by Rigaku Saturn 70 CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated radiation source at 293(2) K, while complex 3 was determined by Rigaku Saturn 724+ CCD diffractometer with confocal-monochromated radiation source at 123(2) K. All of the structures were resolved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELX-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The positions of hydrogen atoms on the organic ligands were generated geometrically and refined using a riding model, while hydrogen atoms of water molecules were set according to Fourier difference maps. The summary of crystallographic data and structure refinements for 1–6 is listed in Table . The selected bond lengths and angles of complexes 1–6 are listed in Tables S1–S6 in the , respectively.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Determination

The single-crystal structure data of complexes 1, 4, and 6 were determined by Mercury CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71071 Å) radiation at room temperature. Complexes 2 and 5 were determined by Rigaku Saturn 70 CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated radiation source at 293(2) K, while complex 3 was determined by Rigaku Saturn 724+ CCD diffractometer with confocal-monochromated radiation source at 123(2) K. All of the structures were resolved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELX-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The positions of hydrogen atoms on the organic ligands were generated geometrically and refined using a riding model, while hydrogen atoms of water molecules were set according to Fourier difference maps. The summary of crystallographic data and structure refinements for 1-6 is listed in Table . The selected bond lengths and angles of complexes 1-6 are listed in Tables S1-S6 in the , respectively.

Solvo­(hydro)­thermal method was employed in these reactions rather than conventional solution reactions. Solvo­(hydro)­thermal reactions, typically carried out in sealed Teflon bombs under autogenous pressure, exploit the self-assembly of the coordination polymers from soluble precursors. The reduced viscosity of solvents under such conditions enhances the diffusion process so that crystal growth from solution is preferred. Under such nonequilibrium crystallization conditions, metastable kinetic phases are most likely to be obtained rather than thermodynamic phases. The reactions of CoCl2·6H2O, H2dpa, and azpy yielded 1 at 160 °C and 2 at 85 °C. It was found that the in situ reduction of azpy to bphy happened in 1 under a high temperature environment. In order to illustrate the reason for the in situ reduction, parallel experiments were performed. Complex 3 was obtained by the same procedure for 1 except that ZnCl2 was used instead of CoCl2·6H2O at 160 °C. While complexes 4 and 5 can be obtained by the same procedures for 2 except that ZnCl2 and MnCl2·4H2O were used instead of CoCl2·6H2O at 85 °C. The shape and color of complexes 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 are shown in Figure . Complex 6 was obtained occasionally under another solvent system, in which we can only obtain the azpy-containing coordination polymer at 85 °C. All phases were obtained in high purity, which were confirmed by PXRD patterns ().
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Solvo(hydro)thermal method was employed in these reactions rather than conventional solution reactions. Solvo(hydro)thermal reactions, typically carried out in sealed Teflon bombs under autogenous pressure, exploit the self-assembly of the coordination polymers from soluble precursors. The reduced viscosity of solvents under such conditions enhances the diffusion process so that crystal growth from solution is preferred. Under such nonequilibrium crystallization conditions, metastable kinetic phases are most likely to be obtained rather than thermodynamic phases. The reactions of CoCl2⋅6H2O, H2dpa, and azpy yielded 1 at 160 °C and 2 at 85 °C. It was found that the in situ reduction of azpy to bphy happened in 1 under a high temperature environment. In order to illustrate the reason for the in situ reduction, parallel experiments were performed. Complex 3 was obtained by the same procedure for 1 except that ZnCl2 was used instead of CoCl2⋅6H2O at 160 °C. While complexes 4 and 5 can be obtained by the same procedures for 2 except that ZnCl2 and MnCl2⋅4H2O were used instead of CoCl2⋅6H2O at 85 °C. The shape and color of complexes 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 are shown in Figure . Complex 6 was obtained occasionally under another solvent system, in which we can only obtain the azpy-containing coordination polymer at 85 °C. All phases were obtained in high purity, which were confirmed by PXRD patterns ().

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complexes 1 and 3 are isostructral, crystallizing in the tetragonal system with P4̅21 c space group. Complex 1 is represented to illustrate both structures. The asymmetry unit of 1 contains half a Co­(II) ion, half a dpa2–, and half a bphy ligand. Co1 adopts a tetrahedral coordination geometry defined by two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O1A) from different carboxylate groups of one dpa2– ligand, and two nitrogen atoms (N1, N1A) from two different bphy ligands (Figure a). The separations of Co–O1 (Co–O1A) and Co–N1 (Co–N1A) are 1.955(1) Å and 2.028(1) Å, respectively, which are quite similar to the normal Co–O, Co–N bonds. The completely deprotonated dpa2– ligands display one kind of coordination mode in complex 1: chelating bis-monodentate mode. The dihedral angle between two phenyls for dpa2– is 62.32°, and the carboxylate groups are out of the plane of corresponding linking phenyl rings with the dihedral angles between them being 51.66°. {Co­(dpa)} nodes occur due to such torsion, which are connected by bphy in gauche-conformation leading to a zigzag chain (Figure b). These discrete chains are interconnected by hydrogen bonding interaction (N2–H2···O2B involving the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atom and the nitrogen atom of bphy) forming a two-dimensional (2D) layer (Figure c), where the N–H···O distance is 2.80(3) Å and the N–H···O angle is 169(2)°. Furthermore, the layers stack in -ABAB- sequence to generate a three-dimensional (3D) plywood-like array through C–H···π interactions between the hydrogen atoms of the benzene rings in dpa2– and the π orbitals of the pyridyl rings in bphy (Figure d). The distances of the C–H···centroid change from 3.536 Å to 3.771 Å (symmetry codes for 1: A, −x, 1 – y, z; B, 1/2 – x, 1/2 + y, 1/2 – z).

Structures

Crystal Structures of [Co(dpa)(bphy)] n  (1) and [Zn(dpa)(bphy)] n  (3)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complexes 1 and 3 are isostructral, crystallizing in the tetragonal system with P4̅21 c space group. Complex 1 is represented to illustrate both structures. The asymmetry unit of 1 contains half a Co(II) ion, half a dpa2-, and half a bphy ligand. Co1 adopts a tetrahedral coordination geometry defined by two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O1A) from different carboxylate groups of one dpa2- ligand, and two nitrogen atoms (N1, N1A) from two different bphy ligands (Figure a). The separations of Co-O1 (Co-O1A) and Co-N1 (Co-N1A) are 1.955(1) Å and 2.028(1) Å, respectively, which are quite similar to the normal Co-O, Co-N bonds. The completely deprotonated dpa2- ligands display one kind of coordination mode in complex 1: chelating bis-monodentate mode. The dihedral angle between two phenyls for dpa2- is 62.32°, and the carboxylate groups are out of the plane of corresponding linking phenyl rings with the dihedral angles between them being 51.66°. {Co(dpa)} nodes occur due to such torsion, which are connected by bphy in gauche-conformation leading to a zigzag chain (Figure b). These discrete chains are interconnected by hydrogen bonding interaction (N2-H2⋅⋅⋅O2B involving the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atom and the nitrogen atom of bphy) forming a two-dimensional (2D) layer (Figure c), where the N-H⋅⋅⋅O distance is 2.80(3) Å and the N-H⋅⋅⋅O angle is 169(2)°. Furthermore, the layers stack in -ABAB- sequence to generate a three-dimensional (3D) plywood-like array through C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the hydrogen atoms of the benzene rings in dpa2- and the π orbitals of the pyridyl rings in bphy (Figure d). The distances of the C-H⋅⋅⋅centroid change from 3.536 Å to 3.771 Å (symmetry codes for 1: A, -x, 1 - y, z; B, 1/2 - x, 1/2 + y, 1/2 - z).

elements.content: Complexes 2 and 5 are isostructural, so complex 2 is employed as a representative to be described in detail. Complex 2 crystallizes in a chiral space group C2. In the asymmetry unit, there are two-half Co­(II) ions, one deprotonated dpa2– ligand, one azpy ligand, and half an uncoordinated water molecule. Co1 is surrounded by four oxygen atoms (O3, O1, O3B, O1B) from each carboxylate group of two dpa2– ligands, and two nitrogen atoms (N1, N4A) from two azpy ligands to furnish a distorted octahedron coordination geometry. Co2 also adopts a distorted octahedral geometry which is ligated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O4, O4C) from two different dpa2–, two pyridyl nitrogen atoms (N5, N8A) and two coordinated water molecules (O5, O5C) (Figure a). The bond lengths of Co–O and Co–N vary from 2.064(1) Å to 2.197(1) Å. The twists between two phenyl rings and corresponding two carboxylate groups in dpa2– are observed with the dihedral angles between them being 65.67°, 61.45°, and 57.38°, respectively. As illustrated in Figure b, the completely deprotonated dpa2– ligands exhibit a bridging monodentate-bidentate mode to connect the neighboring Co­(II) centers in syn-anti conformation forming a one-dimensional (1D) chain. Then the chains are interlinked by azpy, a rod-like linker, giving a 2D rectangular layer (Figure c). The neutral layers are interconnected by C–H···O hydrogen bonds involving the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atom O2D and the pyridyl C18–H18 to generate a supramolecular 3D framework (Figure d). The value of the C···O distance is 3.509 Å (symmetry codes for 2: A, x, 1 + y, z; B, −x, y, −z; C, −x, y, 1 – z; D, −1/2 + x, −1/2 + y, 1/2 – z).

The bond lengths of Co-O and Co-N vary from 2.064(1) Å to 2.197(1) Å. The twists between two phenyl rings and corresponding two carboxylate groups in dpa2- are observed with the dihedral angles between them being 65.67°, 61.45°, and 57.38°, respectively. elements.content: X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 4 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system with Pbcn space group, which features a 1D chain structure. The asymmetry unit of 4 contains half a Zn­(II) ion, half a dpa2– ligand, half a azpy ligand, and half a coordination water molecule. As shown in Figure a, the Zn­(II) center shows a slightly distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry, with two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O1A) and one water molecule (O3) building the trigonal plane, with two pyridyl nitrogen atoms (N1, N1A) filling the axial positions. The bond lengths of Zn1–O1, Zn1–O1A, and Zn1–O3 are 1.989(1), 1.989(1), and 2.020(2) Å, respectively, and Zn1–N1, Zn1–N2 both are 2.183(2) Å, which correspond to those reported complexes. An analogous coordination manner of dpa2– in complex 1 occurs in complex 4. In complex 4, the distortion angles between phenyl rings and corresponding linking carboxylate groups are attached to 60.62° and 50.50°, respectively. These degrees of twist result in the formation of {Zn­(dpa)­(H2O)} nodes, which are connected by azpy giving a 1D linear chain (Figure b). The hydrogen bonding interactions arising from the coordinated water molecules and the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms of dpa2– extend the linear chains to generate a 2D puckered layer (Figure c) (O3–H3A···O2B, with the values of the O···O distance and O–H···O angle being 2.684(2) Å and 173.6°). The adjacent layers stack parallel to each other through weak and slightly offset π···π interactions between the pyridyl rings of azpy and benzene rings of dpa2– (Figure d). The shortest centroid–centroid distance is 4.067 Å (symmetry codes for 4: A, 2 – x, y, 1/2 – z; B, x, −y, 1/2 + z).

Crystal Structure of [Zn(dpa)(azpy)(H2O)] n  (4)

X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 4 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system with Pbcn space group, which features a 1D chain structure. The asymmetry unit of 4 contains half a Zn(II) ion, half a dpa2- ligand, half a azpy ligand, and half a coordination water molecule. As shown in Figure a, the Zn(II) center shows a slightly distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry, with two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O1A) and one water molecule (O3) building the trigonal plane, with two pyridyl nitrogen atoms (N1, N1A) filling the axial positions. The bond lengths of Zn1-O1, Zn1-O1A, and Zn1-O3 are 1.989(1), 1.989(1), and 2.020(2) Å, respectively, and Zn1-N1, Zn1-N2 both are 2.183(2) Å, which correspond to those reported complexes. An analogous coordination manner of dpa2- in complex 1 occurs in complex 4. In complex 4, the distortion angles between phenyl rings and corresponding linking carboxylate groups are attached to 60.62° and 50.50°, respectively. These degrees of twist result in the formation of {Zn(dpa)(H2O)} nodes, which are connected by azpy giving a 1D linear chain (Figure b). The hydrogen bonding interactions arising from the coordinated water molecules and the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms of dpa2- extend the linear chains to generate a 2D puckered layer (Figure c) (O3-H3A⋅⋅⋅O2B, with the values of the O⋅⋅⋅O distance and O-H⋅⋅⋅O angle being 2.684(2) Å and 173.6°). The adjacent layers stack parallel to each other through weak and slightly offset π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the pyridyl rings of azpy and benzene rings of dpa2- (Figure d). The shortest centroid-centroid distance is 4.067 Å (symmetry codes for 4: A, 2 - x, y, 1/2 - z; B, x, -y, 1/2 + z).

elements.content: Complex 6 crystallizes in the triclinic system with P1̅ space group. In the asymmetry unit, there are two distinct crystallography dependent Mn­(II) centers. Each Mn­(II) center is in an octahedral geometry by coordinating to four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three different hexadentate dpa2– ligands and two trans-pyridine nitrogen atoms from different azpy ligands (Figure a). The bond distances of Mn–N vary from 2.293(3) Å to 2.333(3) Å, and Mn–O vary from 2.203(3) Å to 2.152(3) Å, which are comparable to those reported. The only difference between two motifs is the generation of azpy. In motif Mn1, the azpy molecule is crystallography independent, while in motif Mn2, the azpy molecule is built up by application of an inversion center which lies at the midpoint of the azo fragment. The dihedral angle between two phenyls is 69.63°, and the carboxylate groups are out of the plane of corresponding linking phenyl rings with the dihedral angles between them being 33.57°, and 42.07°. The dpa2– ligands with a bridging bis-bidentate coordination mode in complex 6 connect Mn­(II) centers to generate {Mn­(dpa)} n linear chains along the [011] direction, which are interlinked by azpy ligands forming a 2D layer (Figure c). As shown in Figure c,d, the layers constructed from the Mn1 motif and Mn2 motif are parallel to each other and are stacked in -ABAB- fashion yielding a 3D framework via C–H···π interaction established by the hydrogen atoms of the benzene rings in dpa2– and the π orbitals of the pryridyl rings in azpy between the adjacent strands. The value of the C–H···centroid distance is 3.854 Å (symmetry codes for 6: A, x, 1 + y, z; B, –x, y, –z; C, –x, y, 1 – z; D, −1/2 + x, −1/2 + y, 1/2 – z).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Mn(dpa)(azpy)] n ⋅nH2O⋅nMeOH (6)

Complex 6 crystallizes in the triclinic system with P1̅ space group. In the asymmetry unit, there are two distinct crystallography dependent Mn(II) centers. Each Mn(II) center is in an octahedral geometry by coordinating to four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three different hexadentate dpa2- ligands and two trans-pyridine nitrogen atoms from different azpy ligands (Figure a). The bond distances of Mn-N vary from 2.293(3) Å to 2.333(3) Å, and Mn-O vary from 2.203(3) Å to 2.152(3) Å, which are comparable to those reported. The only difference between two motifs is the generation of azpy. In motif Mn1, the azpy molecule is crystallography independent, while in motif Mn2, the azpy molecule is built up by application of an inversion center which lies at the midpoint of the azo fragment. The dihedral angle between two phenyls is 69.63°, and the carboxylate groups are out of the plane of corresponding linking phenyl rings with the dihedral angles between them being 33.57°, and 42.07°. The dpa2- ligands with a bridging bis-bidentate coordination mode in complex 6 connect Mn(II) centers to generate {Mn(dpa)} n  linear chains along the [011] direction, which are interlinked by azpy ligands forming a 2D layer (Figure c). As shown in Figure c,d, the layers constructed from the Mn1 motif and Mn2 motif are parallel to each other and are stacked in -ABAB- fashion yielding a 3D framework via C-H⋅⋅⋅π interaction established by the hydrogen atoms of the benzene rings in dpa2- and the π orbitals of the pryridyl rings in azpy between the adjacent strands. The value of the C-H⋅⋅⋅centroid distance is 3.854 Å (symmetry codes for 6: A, x, 1 + y, z; B, -x, y, -z; C, -x, y, 1 - z; D, -1/2 + x, -1/2 + y, 1/2 - z).

elements.content: The in situ reduction of azpy to bphy was found in complexes 1 and 3, which were confirmed by X-ray crystallographic analyses and LC-MS analyses. The X-ray crystallographic analysis shows that the bond lengths of N–N are 1.391(3) Å in 1 and 1.387(3) Å in 3, respectively. The bond lengths of N–N are comparable to 1.394(7) Å in bphy containing complexes as early reported, while the NN bond lengths are relatively short in complexes 2, 4, 5, and 6 varying from 1.204(7) Å to 1.246(4) Å, which are comparative to reported ones. The list of N–N and NN bond lengths is shown in Table . DMSO was used to decompose the crystalline products 1 and 3, and then the resultant solutions were analyzed by LC-MS, which showed clearly a peak of bphy ().
elements.clean_text:
Reduction of azpy to bphy

The in situ reduction of azpy to bphy was found in complexes 1 and 3, which were confirmed by X-ray crystallographic analyses and LC-MS analyses. The X-ray crystallographic analysis shows that the bond lengths of N-N are 1.391(3) Å in 1 and 1.387(3) Å in 3, respectively. The bond lengths of N-N are comparable to 1.394(7) Å in bphy containing complexes as early reported, while the NN bond lengths are relatively short in complexes 2, 4, 5, and 6 varying from 1.204(7) Å to 1.246(4) Å, which are comparative to reported ones. The list of N-N and NN bond lengths is shown in Table . DMSO was used to decompose the crystalline products 1 and 3, and then the resultant solutions were analyzed by LC-MS, which showed clearly a peak of bphy ().

elements.content: The parallel experiments were carried out by using CoCl2·6H2O, ZnCl2, and MnCl2·4H2O reacting with H2dpa and azpy in H2O/DMF solvent system with the temperatures being 85 and 160 °C. Cobalt, zinc, and manganese containing coordination polymers grew without the in situ reduction at 85 °C, while cobalt and zinc containing coordination polymers were obtained at 160 °C, in which the reduction of azpy to bphy happened. It is found that the coordination polymers with metal centers featuring a four coordination tetrahedral configuration are preferred to form at high temperature. The absence of the Mn-bphy reduction product may be owing to the instability of the four-coordinated Mn­(II) complexes. In fact, only a few examples have been reported to date. Furthermore, we found the reduction products can be obtained in a H2O/DMF solvent system at high temperature, not only on the basis of cobalt­(II) salt with reduction ability but also zinc­(II) salt without reduction ability. Taking all the above discussions into account, we draw conclusions that (i) high temperature conditions presumably play a decisive role to overcome the energy barrier of such a reduction process since the in situ reduction of azpy to bphy is a process that requires bond-breaking and hydrogen transfer, so it is not expected to occur at ordinary temperature owing to the large energy barrier of such a reaction; (ii) due to the presence of a lowing azo-centered π*-orbital, the ligand azpy can be directly populated by one or two electrons chemically or electrochemically. So the reduction of azpy through a two-electron process probably happens, which has been reported early. We speculate that water is an accessory as a reductant, which provides electrons and protons for this in situ reduction. The speculation is highly consistence with that reported; (iii) metal ions may not take effect as the reductants, but play a role on the self-assembly of coordination polymers.

Recently, there has been increasing interest in constructing homochiral coordination polymers as heterogeneous catalysts for enantioselective catalysis, separation, etc. Most homochiral coordination polymers have been obtained by using enantiopure organic ligands. However, the chirality can also be generated from achiral ligands without any chiral additives through a process called spontaneous resolution based on the statistical fluctuation of initial nucleation events. During this spontaneous resolution process, symmetry breaking could be driven by supramolecular interactions, making the resulting bulky product homochiral.
elements.clean_text:
Circular Dichroism in 2 and 5 

Recently, there has been increasing interest in constructing homochiral coordination polymers as heterogeneous catalysts for enantioselective catalysis, separation, etc. Most homochiral coordination polymers have been obtained by using enantiopure organic ligands. However, the chirality can also be generated from achiral ligands without any chiral additives through a process called spontaneous resolution based on the statistical fluctuation of initial nucleation events. During this spontaneous resolution process, symmetry breaking could be driven by supramolecular interactions, making the resulting bulky product homochiral.

elements.content: For the current case in our work, complexes 2 and 5 crystallize in a chiral space group C2 with Flack parameters of 0.028(1) and 0.014(2), respectively, which indicate enantiomeric purity of the single crystals despite the use of achiral reagents. CD spectra of single crystals of 2 and 5 were measured in the solid state. In order to better validate the chiral properties, more than 10 randomly selected single crystals of 2 and 5 with sufficient sizes and quantities from the same crystallization were used for the CD measurements as well as for single-crystal X-ray studies. It is found that all results indicate a positive Cotton effect (Figure ), revealing the homochiral nature of complexes 2 and 5. The outcomes are in accord with the structures obtained by single-crystal X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: At the single crystal level, the origin of chirality of these two complexes is associated with the asymmetrical coordinated modes of dpa2– ligands on the basis of metal ions, which make them crystallize in chiral space groups. In complexes 1, 3, and 4, the dpa2– ligands exhibit completely symmetry coordination environments, which cause those achiral structures. Despite the asymmetry coordination mode of dpa2– in complex 6, the existence of an inversion center makes it remain achiral. The coordination modes of dpa2– and the dihedral angles between phenyl and carboxylate group are listed in .

elements.content: On the other hand, the homochirality of the bulky samples contributes to asymmetry breaking in spontaneous asymmetrical crystallization. The hydrogen bonds constructed by C–H···O could contribute to such asymmetry breaking phenomenon, which might control the initial nucleation, making the seed effect take a preference in the formation of one handedness of crystals over the other.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, the homochirality of the bulky samples contributes to asymmetry breaking in spontaneous asymmetrical crystallization. The hydrogen bonds constructed by C-H⋅⋅⋅O could contribute to such asymmetry breaking phenomenon, which might control the initial nucleation, making the seed effect take a preference in the formation of one handedness of crystals over the other.

elements.content: Coordination polymers with d10 metal centers and conjugated organic linkers are promising candidates for luminescent materials, which have been investigated owing to their fluorescent properties and potential applications. Therefore, the solid-state luminescent properties of complexes 3 and 4 have been studied at room temperature. For the sake of understanding the emission mechanism, we also studied the luminescent properties of the free ligands. As shown in Figure , free ligand azpy exhibits a blue emission band at 445 nm upon excitation at 350 nm, which could be ascribed to intraligand charge transfer (n-π* or π–π*). Compared with the emission of azpy, the emissive peak is located at 445 nm (λex = 350 nm) for complex 4. Since the profile and location of the emission band of 4 are exactly same with free azpy, it can be assigned mainly to intraligand n-π* or π–π* transition. However, its decreased emissive intensity is probably due to the quenching effect of the coordinated water molecule. In complex 3, the formation of bphy decreases the π-conjugation, so bphy should possess a higher energy gap between excited and ground states than azpy, thus giving an emission at a little shorter wavelength. It can be presumed that the emission band at 450 nm (λex = 350 nm) of complex 3 may be attributed to the Zn-perturbed intraligand n-π* or π–π* transition of the bphy ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent and SHG Properties

Coordination polymers with d10 metal centers and conjugated organic linkers are promising candidates for luminescent materials, which have been investigated owing to their fluorescent properties and potential applications. Therefore, the solid-state luminescent properties of complexes 3 and 4 have been studied at room temperature. For the sake of understanding the emission mechanism, we also studied the luminescent properties of the free ligands. As shown in Figure , free ligand azpy exhibits a blue emission band at 445 nm upon excitation at 350 nm, which could be ascribed to intraligand charge transfer (n-π* or π-π*). Compared with the emission of azpy, the emissive peak is located at 445 nm (λex = 350 nm) for complex 4. Since the profile and location of the emission band of 4 are exactly same with free azpy, it can be assigned mainly to intraligand n-π* or π-π* transition. However, its decreased emissive intensity is probably due to the quenching effect of the coordinated water molecule. In complex 3, the formation of bphy decreases the π-conjugation, so bphy should possess a higher energy gap between excited and ground states than azpy, thus giving an emission at a little shorter wavelength. It can be presumed that the emission band at 450 nm (λex = 350 nm) of complex 3 may be attributed to the Zn-perturbed intraligand n-π* or π-π* transition of the bphy ligand.

elements.content: To confirm the acentricity of complexes 1 and 3, Second harmonic generation (SHG) measurements on the powder samples of them have been performed. Preliminary experimental results show that the bulk materials for both complexes display powder SHG efficiencies which are comparative to potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP).

elements.content: The magnetic behaviors for polycrystalline complexes 1, 2, 5, and 6 have been measured at a temperature range of 2–300 K under an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe. The temperature dependencies of χM T and χM –1 versus T (χM is the magnetic susceptibility per one formula unit) are presented in Figure . For complexes 1 and 2, the experimental χM T at 300 K are 2.65 and 2.88 cm3 K mol–1, which are consistent with the typical value of the Co­(II) ion (normally ranging from 2.7 to 3.4 cm3 K mol–1). In complex 1, the χM T value decreases to 2.38 cm3 K mol–1 at 17.4 K and rapidly increases to a sharp maximum value of 2.68 cm3 K mol–1 at 10 K, and then finally drops until the lowest temperature 2 K. In complex 2, there is a continuous decrease in the value of χM T as the temperature is lowered from 300 to 3.9 K, at which the χM T reaches a minimum value of 2.01 cm3 K mol–1. Upon further lowering of the temperature, χM T increases to 2.11 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. The susceptibilities of 1 and 2 above 50 K fit well with the Curie–Weiss law with C = +2.63 and +3.02 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −1.49 and −11.61 K. The negative Weiss constants indicate overall antiferromagnetic coupling between Co­(II) ions. For complexes 5 and 6, the experimental χM T at 300 K are 3.85 and 3.83 cm3 K mol–1, respectively, which are smaller than the spin-only (g = 2) value of 4.375 cm3 K mol–1 for a spin ground state S = 5/2. Upon cooling, the χM T values decrease slightly to 3.79 cm3 K mol–1 for 5 and 3.69 cm3 K mol–1 for 6 at 50 K, and then decrease dramatically to 0.76 cm3 K mol–1 for 5 and 1.53 cm3 K mol–1 for 6 at 2 K. The susceptibilities of 5 and 6 above 50 K obey the Curie–Weiss law with the Curie constants C = +3.88 and +3.86 cm3 K mol–1, and the Weiss constants θ = −0.60 and −0.05 K, which indicate the weak antiferromagnetic interaction between the Mn­(II) ions

In complex 2, there is a continuous decrease in the value of χM T as the temperature is lowered from 300 to 3.9 K, at which the χM T reaches a minimum value of 2.01 cm3 K mol-1. Upon cooling, the χM T values decrease slightly to 3.79 cm3 K mol-1 for 5 and 3.69 cm3 K mol-1 for 6 at 50 K, and then decrease dramatically to 0.76 cm3 K mol-1 for 5 and 1.53 cm3 K mol-1 for 6 at 2 K. elements.content: Six low-dimensional coordination polymers have been obtained on the basis of 2,2′-biphenyldicarboxylate and 4,4′-azobispyridine in the presence of different transition metal ions by solvothermal methods. Both complexes 1 and 3 feature plywood-like structures, which possess SHG efficiencies that are comparable to KDP, while complex 4 exhibits a parallel chains array. Complexes 2 and 5 affording 2D chiral (4,4) networks show bulky homochirality which might be driven by symmetry breaking during a spontaneous asymmetrical crystallization process. And complex 6 affords parallel (4,4) networks. These 1D chain or 2D layer coordination polymers are extended through hydrogen bonding and π···π interactions to 3D supramolecular architectures. In situ formation of 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­hydrazine from reduction of 4,4′-azobispyridine at high temperature has been found. We speculated that during such a reduction process, in which water is considered as a reductant, temperature plays an important role to overcome the energy barrier in the formation of the final products. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that cobalt and manganese complexes exhibit antiferromagnetic coupling interactions. This work provides a new method for further syntheses of novelty coordination polymers with in situ generation of ligand under solvothermal conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Six low-dimensional coordination polymers have been obtained on the basis of 2,2'-biphenyldicarboxylate and 4,4'-azobispyridine in the presence of different transition metal ions by solvothermal methods. Both complexes 1 and 3 feature plywood-like structures, which possess SHG efficiencies that are comparable to KDP, while complex 4 exhibits a parallel chains array. Complexes 2 and 5 affording 2D chiral (4,4) networks show bulky homochirality which might be driven by symmetry breaking during a spontaneous asymmetrical crystallization process. And complex 6 affords parallel (4,4) networks. These 1D chain or 2D layer coordination polymers are extended through hydrogen bonding and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions to 3D supramolecular architectures. In situ formation of 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)hydrazine from reduction of 4,4'-azobispyridine at high temperature has been found. We speculated that during such a reduction process, in which water is considered as a reductant, temperature plays an important role to overcome the energy barrier in the formation of the final products. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that cobalt and manganese complexes exhibit antiferromagnetic coupling interactions. This work provides a new method for further syntheses of novelty coordination polymers with in situ generation of ligand under solvothermal conditions.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of CoCl2·6H2O (0.144 g, 0.6 mmol), H2dpa (0.048 g, 0.2 mmol), azpy (0.036 g, 0.2 mmol), H2O (8 mL), and DMF (2 mL) was sealed in a 24 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and then heated at 160 °C for 4 days. After slowly cooling to room temperature over 24 h, the purple prism crystals suitable for X-ray structural analysis were isolated by filtration, washed with water several times, and dried in air. Yield: ca. 37.12% (based on CoCl2·6H2O). Anal. Calcd for C24H18N4O4Co1: C, 59.39; H, 3.74; N, 11.54. Found: C, 59.34; H, 3.74; N, 11.63. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3455 (w), 2907 (w), 1638 (s), 1530 (m), 1494 (w), 1347 (m), 830 (m), 746 (m), 672 (m).

Synthesis of [Co­(dpa)­(azpy)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>·0.5<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

A solution of CoCl2·6H2O (0.144 g, 0.6 mmol), H2dpa (0.048 g, 0.2 mmol), azpy (0.036 g, 0.2 mmol), H2O (8 mL), and DMF (2 mL) was sealed in a 15 mL scintillation vial. The contents were sonicated until dissolved, then heated at 85 °C for 4 days. The cuboid red crystals were obtained and collected by filtration. Yield: ca. 39.20% (based on CoCl2.6H2O). Anal. Calcd for C24H19N4O5.5Co1: C, 56.01; H, 3.75; N, 11.10. Found: C, 56.48; H, 3.75; N, 10.98. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3748 (w), 3464 (w), 2930 (w), 1614 (w), 1500 (m), 1452 (w), 830 (s), 686 (w), 612 (m).

Synthesis of [Zn­(dpa)­(bphy)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

A similar synthesis procedure for complex 1 was adopted to prepare complex 3, except that ZnCl2 (0.084 g, 0.6 mmol) was used instead of CoCl2·6H2O. The yellow crystals of 3 were collected by filtration. Yield: ca. 38.73% (based on ZnCl2). Anal. Calcd for C24H18N4O4Zn1: C, 58.61; H, 3.69; N, 11.39. Found: C, 58.69; H, 3.62; N, 11.38. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3436 (w), 2900 (m), 1630 (s), 1530 (m), 1496 (m), 1356 (s), 834 (m), 756 (m), 682 (m).

Synthesis of [Zn­(dpa)­(azpy)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

A similar synthesis procedure for complex 2 was adopted to prepare complex 4, except that ZnCl2 (0.084 g, 0.6 mmol) was used instead of CoCl2·6H2O as the starting material. The cuboid red crystals of 4 were obtained and collected by filtration, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield: ca. 38.42% (based on ZnCl2). Anal. Calcd for C24H18N4O5Zn1: C, 56.76; H, 3.57; N, 11.03. Found: C, 56.78; H, 3.57; N, 11.13. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3442 (s), 2928 (w), 1600 (s), 1382­(m), 843(s), 782 (w), 680 (w).

Synthesis of [Mn­(dpa)­(azpy)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>·0.5<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>5</bold>)

A similar synthesis procedure for complex 2 was adopted to prepare complex 5, except that CoCl2·6H2O was replaced by MnCl2·4H2O (0.120 g, 0.6 mmol). The orange crystals of 5 grew slowly along with the evaporation of filtrate. Yield: ca. 41.37% (based on MnCl2·4H2O). Anal. Calcd for C24H19N4O5.5Mn1: C, 56.93; H, 3.78; N, 11.06. Found: C, 56.68; H, 3.75; N, 11.12. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3750 (w), 3464 (w), 2921 (w), 1613 (w), 1500 (m), 1448 (w), 836 (s), 686 (w), 610 (m).

Synthesis of [Mn­(dpa)­(azpy)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>·<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>H<sub>2</sub>O·<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>MeOH (<bold>6</bold>)

A mixture of MnCl2·4H2O (0.060 g, 0.3 mmol), H2dpa (0.024 g, 0.1 mmol), azpy (0.018 g, 0.1 mmol), MeOH (5 mL), and DMF (5 mL) was sealed in a 15 mL scintillation vial. The contents were sonicated for 10 min, and then heated at 85 °C for 3 days. The plate-like red crystals suitable for the single-crystal X-ray diffraction study were obtained. Yield: ca. 45.72% (based on MnCl2·4H2O). Anal.Calcd for C49H38N8O10Mn2: C, 58.34; H, 3.79; N, 11.12. Found: C, 57.48; H, 3.77; N, 11.16. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3749 (w), 3464 (w), 2927 (w), 1610 (w), 1500 (m), 1448 (w), 835 (s), 684 (w), 610 (m).

cln_elements.content: The magnetic behaviors for polycrystalline complexes 1, 2, 5, and 6 have been measured at a temperature range of 2–300 K under an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe. The temperature dependencies of χM T and χM –1 versus T (χM is the magnetic susceptibility per one formula unit) are presented in Figure . For complexes 1 and 2, the experimental χM T at 300 K are 2.65 and 2.88 cm3 K mol–1, which are consistent with the typical value of the Co­(II) ion (normally ranging from 2.7 to 3.4 cm3 K mol–1). In complex 1, the χM T value decreases to 2.38 cm3 K mol–1 at 17.4 K and rapidly increases to a sharp maximum value of 2.68 cm3 K mol–1 at 10 K, and then finally drops until the lowest temperature 2 K. In complex 2, there is a continuous decrease in the value of χM T as the temperature is lowered from 300 to 3.9 K, at which the χM T reaches a minimum value of 2.01 cm3 K mol–1. Upon further lowering of the temperature, χM T increases to 2.11 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. The susceptibilities of 1 and 2 above 50 K fit well with the Curie–Weiss law with C = +2.63 and +3.02 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −1.49 and −11.61 K. The negative Weiss constants indicate overall antiferromagnetic coupling between Co­(II) ions. For complexes 5 and 6, the experimental χM T at 300 K are 3.85 and 3.83 cm3 K mol–1, respectively, which are smaller than the spin-only (g = 2) value of 4.375 cm3 K mol–1 for a spin ground state S = 5/2. Upon cooling, the χM T values decrease slightly to 3.79 cm3 K mol–1 for 5 and 3.69 cm3 K mol–1 for 6 at 50 K, and then decrease dramatically to 0.76 cm3 K mol–1 for 5 and 1.53 cm3 K mol–1 for 6 at 2 K. The susceptibilities of 5 and 6 above 50 K obey the Curie–Weiss law with the Curie constants C = +3.88 and +3.86 cm3 K mol–1, and the Weiss constants θ = −0.60 and −0.05 K, which indicate the weak antiferromagnetic interaction between the Mn­(II) ions
cln_elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The magnetic behaviors for polycrystalline complexes 1, 2, 5, and 6 have been measured at a temperature range of 2-300 K under an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe. The temperature dependencies of χM T and χM -1 versus T (χM is the magnetic susceptibility per one formula unit) are presented in Figure . For complexes 1 and 2, the experimental χM T at 300 K are 2.65 and 2.88 cm3 K mol-1, which are consistent with the typical value of the Co(II) ion (normally ranging from 2.7 to 3.4 cm3 K mol-1). In complex 1, the χM T value decreases to 2.38 cm3 K mol-1 at 17.4 K and rapidly increases to a sharp maximum value of 2.68 cm3 K mol-1 at 10 K, and then finally drops until the lowest temperature 2 K. In complex 2, there is a continuous decrease in the value of χM T as the temperature is lowered from 300 to 3.9 K, at which the χM T reaches a minimum value of 2.01 cm3 K mol-1. Upon further lowering of the temperature, χM T increases to 2.11 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. The susceptibilities of 1 and 2 above 50 K fit well with the Curie-Weiss law with C = +2.63 and +3.02 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = -1.49 and -11.61 K. The negative Weiss constants indicate overall antiferromagnetic coupling between Co(II) ions. For complexes 5 and 6, the experimental χM T at 300 K are 3.85 and 3.83 cm3 K mol-1, respectively, which are smaller than the spin-only (g = 2) value of 4.375 cm3 K mol-1 for a spin ground state S = 5/2. Upon cooling, the χM T values decrease slightly to 3.79 cm3 K mol-1 for 5 and 3.69 cm3 K mol-1 for 6 at 50 K, and then decrease dramatically to 0.76 cm3 K mol-1 for 5 and 1.53 cm3 K mol-1 for 6 at 2 K. The susceptibilities of 5 and 6 above 50 K obey the Curie-Weiss law with the Curie constants C = +3.88 and +3.86 cm3 K mol-1, and the Weiss constants θ = -0.60 and -0.05 K, which indicate the weak antiferromagnetic interaction between the Mn(II) ions
